awd_titl_txt: Supporting Scholars to Succeed in STEM (S4) Program
awd_abstract_narration:
Mount St. Mary's University (MSMU) is a federally designated Hispanic Serving Institution (HSI) in Los Angeles consisting of two campuses.  The main campus (Chalon) in West Los Angeles offers Baccalaureate degrees in 31 majors. The downtown (Doheny) Campus offers two-year Associate Degree programs and graduate programs. MSMU primarily serves women and has a long-standing commitment to providing quality programs to under-served and financially disadvantaged students. This project entitled "Supporting Scholars to Succeed in STEM (S4) Program" will support strong education and leadership opportunities for an ethnically diverse population.   New knowledge is added to existing research via the design and construction of the S4 data dashboard to track impacts of each program activity on STEM enrollment, retention, success, and graduation of low income women.  Eighteen talented students will be recruited and provided with S-STEM scholarships to retain, support and graduate the students into the workforce or to graduate programs.

Research indicates that institutions with high retention rates consistently use retention software incorporating an early alert system to identify students at risk of dropping out. Building upon this research the S4 program will improve data analytics and early alert mechanisms by creating the S4 dashboard to identify factors contributing to low retention and graduation rates, to diagnose these factors and enable the leadership team to use the data reports generated to inform targeted responses. The analysis of on-track indicators by discipline and student subgroup, will enable the team to understand which milestones students are failing to reach, which subgroups are struggling most to reach each milestone, and why students are not reaching specific milestones. The research enables STEM faculty, administrators, and student support staff to identify the variables contributing to low retention and graduation rates. The aim is to diagnose the results of the various strategies used to ensure success, to measure the impact of each curricular and co-curricular support service thereby helping the Leadership team to make data driven improvements to curriculum, instruction, support services and institutional policies.  An external evaluator will provide formative and summative evaluation applications and metrics for each of the project's five program objectives.

por.por_cntn:
The National Science Foundation (NSF) Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics Program (S-STEM) supports institutions of higher education to fund scholarships for academically talented low-income students and to study and implement a program of activities that support their recruitment, retention, and graduation in STEM.

The NSF S-STEM grant was awarded to Mount Saint Mary's University (MSMU) in 2016. Our program, Supporting Scholars to Succeed in STEM (S4), had the following goals: (I) Supplement institution-wide efforts to increase STEM retention rate and enrollment at Mount Saint Mary's University; (II) establish new strategies to address the needs of low-income STEM students; (III) identify strategies to improve the educational outcome of STEM students such as preparedness for STEM careers and graduate programs. Over the course of the grant, S4 program leadership recruited and retained through graduation 19 academically talented low-income students (for this report, Scholars) from diverse backgrounds. For the majority of Scholars, the number of years of program support was three to four. Four participating Scholars entered the program in their freshman year, nine in their sophomore year, five in their junior year, and one in her senior year. At the conclusion of this grant, we saw the most academic success in Scholars that were in the S4 program the longest, which was four years. These individuals had the support they needed at different stages of their academic career, from their first year to their senior year.

A key finding of the S4 project at MSMU is that a comprehensive, holistic, collaborative approach is essential to meeting the needs of traditionally underserved and low-income STEM students. During the time that Scholars were participating in our S4 program, in addition to financial scholarship support, they received one-on-one faculty mentoring, peer mentoring, and academic supplemental instruction. Scholars participated in summer research internships, conducted their own undergraduate research projects with our STEM research faculty on campus, and presented their research at national and regional STEM conferences. The S4 program developed specific workshops and individual engagements with STEM faculty that focused on career and graduate school application and preparedness, and also very importantly through collaboration with other campus offices on physical and mental/emotional support and wellness.

The COVID-19 pandemic serves as a dramatic demonstration of the program's approach and success. Regarding the S4 program, enrollment retention rates remained high throughout the program period. Even during Year 3 following the Getty Fire (a fall 2019 wildfire in Los Angeles that severely damaged MSMU's Chalon Campus), and Year 4 which saw the onset of unprecedented challenges represented by the COVID-19 pandemic, the S4 Scholars program saw no students drop out, no leaves of absence taken by Scholars, and a high average GPA among participating Scholars. Relative to their fellow STEM students, S4 program Scholars graduated earlier at a high rate, with 100% of S4 Scholars graduating within 4 years and one semester. One hundred percent of graduated Scholars earned a cumulative GPA of 3.0 or above, and 68.4% earned 3.5 or above. Graduated Scholars continue to move forward in their STEM careers by applying for graduate STEM programs. One former student is completing a PhD program in Geography at UCLA; others are currently in graduate STEM and medical programs at the University of Southern California (USC), City University of New York (CUNY), and others. 89.4% of graduated Scholars are currently either in a STEM/medical graduate program or working in a STEM/medical industry or institution, including one graduated Scholar doing molecular Biology research as a PREP scholar at Johns Hopkins University.

Especially encouraging are program evaluation interviews that emphasize the value Scholars identified in such factors as a) mentorship and relationships with faculty and with each other, b) the financial support which allowed students to focus on studies without needing to earn outside employment, and c) the value of workshops that not only focused on academic development, career and graduate school preparedness, but also on health and mental/emotional health. We feel this is indicative of the merits of S4 and similar programs, as it demonstrates how-together with financial support-comprehensive engagement in students' well-being, close mentorship, and sense of community are vital to the success of academically talented low-income students.

In October 2021 the project team published a paper titled "Attracting and retaining Latina women in an undergraduate program" in the Journal of STEM Education, Volume 22, Issue 4, October-December 2021. An abstract and the full paper are accessible via the following link: https://jstem.org/jstem/index.php/JSTEM/article/view/2518

 

 


Last Modified: 01/17/2023
Modified by: Afsane Arvand
